title: Parents said that League of Legends was ruining my life.
body:
League of legends is just a game right?  At least that's what parents say. They believe that videogames are something that takes time away from other, "productive" things we could be doing. Here's my side of the story.

I started league back in September 2012. This was the end of season 3. I got hooked on the game immediately, and spammed normal all day to get to level 30. I remember going through Mobafire guides, youtube videos. Anything related to League - I was there. I'd think about league while at school too. Eventually it became to be a bit of a problem. When I was once a straight A student with AP's and college classes on the side,  I began to fail my classes. I would stay up into the early hours of the morning playing. I then started ranked, and hit bronze 5. I was a typical bronze player, ragey , shitty mechanics, no idea what I was doing. I was addicted to league though. My parents made me stop cold turkey for 4-5 months until I got my shit together. After my hiatus, I came back to league. I still played hard, but made sure my school stuff got done. This is where I began my climb, getting into silver, gold, platinum, diamond.  My parents still thought that League had taken away and wasted a big part of my life. All those nights staying up playing ranked instead of out with friends. I even thought to myself that I had wasted my entire highschool experience. How wrong I was.

On my EUW account I recently hit Diamond 1, which is a pretty big milestone. Now for lack of time, a lot of this is sped up. It seemed really quick though , right? Bronze 5 to Diamond 1. It took me around 2500 hours of gameplay to get that far. I got into streaming along the way, and started accumulating followers and viewers. I eventually got contacted by boosting companies wanting to hire me, as well as random companies wanting to sponsor me (Eluxy Computers for example). I also heard about League of Legends scholarships, and applied for them. I recently found out I got in, and that I'd be playing for University of Pikeville on a League of Legends scholarship. In my application I put in attention grabbers, avid sponsored streamer , 3rd best vayne NA (statwise), etc. I'm also turning my major (as I'm a college student now) into E-sports management in aims of managing pro teams in the future. 

Why did I post this? And again, I know it seems really sped up. My climb on the solo queue ladder, as well as opportunity wise. It took  a lot of time to get to this point, a lot of time I could have spent having a girlfriend or going out on Fridays. What I'm saying is, League of legends is not just a game. If you put the time in, some of you can make a career out of it. Not everyone's gonna make it, some just don't have enough time, some dont have enough potential. But I hope this can inspire you to keep playing and play with a deadest purpose.

EDIT: This was a post I made back in '12 when I was Bronze and ruined my grades, and had all internet usage taken away. Some of you may be in similar situations. http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=3470877

Oh man, the despair of life really is finding something you enjoy but realising it's simply impossible for you to go there.

The key difference is that an addiction is something that is exceedingly difficult to break, even if the addicted person wishes to do so. You doing something that you find fun a lot is not an addiction because there is no evidence that you couldn't wish should you stop to enjoy it - sometimes people get bored of what they find fun and just stop playing. Not an addiction.

It's an addiction when despite no longer getting pleasure from it, you are unable to stop. That is why stuff like the classic "I'll quit smoking tomorrow" joke exists - a lot of smokers are entirely aware of the negative impacts of what they do, and get little actual pleasure from their smoking, but continue it because their body cannot handle them stopping. You are not necessarily suffering when addicted, as a smoker may still enjoy their smoking, but when you get to the point where you don't actually like what you're addicted to anymore but can't quit regardless, that's suffering.

Jg/top, generally the roles that spend the least amount of time fighting alongside teammates.

I don't know a whole bunch about top, but some good champs to learn are Irelia and Hecarim. Both very good lane phases, scale decently well, and have a lot of roam and TP potential. A lot of what carrying is is roaming, except for possibly ADC. Many lower elo tops will not tp or don't even take tp because they don't want to miss farm. However 1 tp to bot lane can win a game. If you've pushed your lane out, go and roam mid. Jungle is all about the early pressure. You need to gank before the other jungler does, or counter gank. For example, most junglers will start their route at the bottom side of the map so they get a good leash from ADC. This means they'll generally look to go top first. You can take advantage of that by sitting in a top brush and wait for the counter gank. It's so hard to tell you everything in one comment though.

Hey man, good for you! Allow me to give you some advice, free of charge though. Take it as you will.

1. Don't plan on making this a full career. E-sports come and go. It wasn't long ago that SC2 was the hot game to be in. The second LoL slips out of the spotlight, you'll have nothing else. 

2. Do NOT go into E-sports management. I've actually talked with my counselor about E-sports. The issue is that being an manager of a gaming team does not look well going into other jobs. People see it as a frivolous thing, as a job with minimal responsibilities. True or not, this is people's perceptions, and it will make a difference. My advice is to go into business management, then branch out from there.

3. More on the personal level here, but just getting a scholarship to a university doesn't mean much. It depends on the scholarship itself, and more importantly, on the university in question. Getting even a partial scholarship to any well known school is infinetly better than getting a full ride through a small no-name private college. Employers aren't going to outright say it, but they're going to be much more inclined to hire a student from a top university than others. 

4. Nitpicking but.. 

> But I hope this can inspire you to keep playing and play with a deadest purpose.

I have no idea what this means.

I'll probably end up going into BM and if E-sports opportunities come up I'll take them. If I got the chance to be an E-sports manager, I would take it any day.  And when you say "people" see it as a frivolous thing, you do realize that most older people don't really know about League, or about what being an e-sports manager entails? So how could "people" see it as a frivolous thing? Even most league players don't know what being an e-sports manager entails. And meant to say "play with a deadest" purpose.

There's a big difference between you, who worked at it and is using the opportunities to your advantage, and 99.99% of everyone else that thinks the same but just plays the game. I hope the people who take your story as an example to follow figure out which percent they want to be a part of.
